text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column divided into three horizontal registers by simple rules. Each register contains one or more images with adjacent red-ink labels, all enclosed within a plain rectangular frame. Textual labels sit directly above, below or beside each miniature, integrating word and image closely. Margins are narrow and unadorned, directing focus to the compartmentalized zones. Visual hierarchy is flat: no single image dominates, each panel is equal in size.

text_content.script_style: Transitional proto-Gothic book hand with red rubrication; consistent letterforms, moderate use of ligatures and abbreviations, ruled guidelines faintly visible

color_scheme.color_usage: Red exclusively used for captions and emphases; green applied sparingly to highlight specific objects (e.g., hill, purse) and occasional garments. Brown ink underdrawing remains visible beneath light washes. No metallic pigments; overall palette restrained, serving mnemonic rather than decorative aims.

features: Images aligned in register, separated by simple rules
Adjacent text labels anchoring each figure/object
Flat spatial treatment without depth cues

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill pen lines in brown iron gall ink; uniform weight, clear contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal; flat washes of green or brown, no hatching or chiaroscuro
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Absent linear perspective; figures and objects sized for clarity, not spatial accuracy; registers stacked without overlap

scene_relationships.subject: Planetary deities and astrophilosophical symbols (e.g., Saturn with nude figure, attendant figures)
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Shifts from celestial bodies to terrestrial implements
visual_connections: Use of red captions for identification
Green wash used in each register
Figures facing inward toward central element

scene_relationships.subject: Human figure with axe, purse (marsupium), and portable writing desk
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Transitions from human activities to animal world
visual_connections: Brown line and green accent continuity
Central vertical alignment under top register elements
Similar figure scale to top attendants

scene_relationships.subject: Various fauna: lion hindquarter, bird head, horned animal
visual_connections: Imagery placed left-to-right in consistent order

visual_continuity: Consistent brown ink outlines across all scenes
Green wash used sparingly in each register

content_theme.scene_description: Top register: Two standing male attendants in tunics approach the bust of Saturn, rendered with a halo-like planetary symbol inscribed ‘Saturnus’, who holds a small nude female figure (personification of a metal or quality). To the right are three smaller object studies: a stylized hill, a rectangular bronze ingot, and a suspended purse or bag, each labeled in red. Figures wear simple garments with minimal modeling; scale is schematic. Spatially they occupy a shallow band, with no background beyond a ruled border. Costume details include knee-length tunics, hose, pointed shoes. The planetary head has a partially stylized beard and large eyes; the nude figure is drawn frontally, arms at sides. The whole serves as an encyclopedic mnemonic of astrological-metallurgical correspondences.

secular: Two male attendants in top register wearing tunics and hose
Middle register figure in tunic with red scarf holding an axe
symbolic: Saturn personified as a bearded bust holding a nude female figure

technical_features.material: Calfskin vellum, single leaf from a quaternion, lightly scraped and pumiced for smooth writing surface; faint ruling visible in brown ink
technical_features.preservation_condition: Good overall; slight discoloration of parchment, minor flaking of green wash, red rubrics remain vivid, no major tears or losses
notable_physical_characteristics: Underdrawing visible under green wash in animal figures
Consistent ruling pattern at 2.5 cm intervals
Brown iron gall ink outlines with light brush-applied washes

secondary_functions: Reference tool for clerics or lay scholars
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Scholarly community or advanced students in a cathedral school or early university context

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This page exemplifies a thirteenth-century encyclopedic tradition, likely produced in a school or university setting where mnemonic imagery aided the teaching of astronomy, metallurgy and natural history. The compartmentalized layout and restrained palette reflect pedagogical priorities over luxury: clear brown ink outlines, red-ink captions, and sparing green washes maximize legibility. The personification of Saturn holding a nude figure suggests a conceptual link between planets and metals, drawing on classical and Arabic scientific sources. The middle register’s tools and the bottom register’s animal fragments demonstrate a miscellany of technical and natural knowledge, characteristic of early scholastic miscellanies. Stylistically, the fine abrasions and uniform line indicate a professional workshop familiar with educational manuscripts rather than a luxury illuminator working for a noble patron. Compared to contemporary Gothic bestiaries, this compilation is more schematic and utilitarian, lacking decorative borders or gold leaf. Yet its precise line work and clear labeling attest to a sophisticated grasp of didactic visualization. It bridges the monastic manuscript culture with emerging university practices, reflecting the growing thirst for organized knowledge in the later Middle Ages.
